Comment: I’m in Japan for two weeks and I’ve been so impressed with how easy it was to get around from Tokyo, Hakone, and Kamakura purely through public transportation.  There’s vending machines and convenience stores every block or so if I need a drink or snack.  The trains and busses are decently clean considering how often they’re used.   Im from the Bay Area, one of the wealthier parts of the US and it feels like our infrastructure is stuck in the early 2000s.  Really makes you wonder what are we even paying all these taxes for.

Comment: Notice what else was going on during those years? The cold war. The oligarchs, aka the capitalists, made some concessions to the working class because of they were threatened by a communist revolution. They had to sell capitalism, a system that had led to two world wars, and the exploitation of most people on earth against a system that despite it's flaws was lifting millions out of poverty. They had to prove that they weren't just as racists as the recently defeated Nazis so they allowed some concessions for civil rights.  However once the Soviet Union collapsed and China liberalized, the oligarchs were suddenly safe from the working class revolt, so they took back the concessions they had made during the cold war.

Comment: Lifelong resident, NIMBYism also known as “not in my backyard” has a chokehold on the state for sure. People are so quick to complain about the lack of anything in their town but are also the same people that refuse to let any new developments happen.  I was looking at google maps of the northern border recently out of general curiosity and was astounded at what the US/Canadian boarder looks like. On one side is beautifully designed neighborhoods, towns, urban development, then right across the boarder, same climate, same resources, and it’s just fuckin acres of forest. Blew my mind how left behind we are up here. But in a way that’s sort of what makes Maine so special. It’s one of the last “great frontiers untouched by man”.
